concepts.unlisted_label: Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1957 (Punjab Act 39 of 1957)
concepts.unlisted_description: Act for resumption of jagirs including assignments of land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2  1  defines jagir as follows- jagir means-  a  any assignment of land revenue made by or on behalf of the State Government or  b  any estate in land created or affirmed by or on behalf of the State Government carrying with it the right of companylecting land revenue or receiving any portion of the land revenue or  c any grant of money made or companytinued by or on behalf of the State Government which purports to be or is expressed to be payable out of the land revenue or  d  any grant of money including anything payable on the part of the State Government in respect of any right, privilege, perquisite or office and includes any such grant or assignment existing in favour of Cis-Sutlej jagirdars.

concepts.interpretation: Cis-Sutlej jagirs fall within clause (a) as implied assignments of land revenue by State Government (including predecessors).

anchor.surface_text: Section 2  5  defines State Government as follows- State Government-  a  as respects any period before the 1st November 1956, shall mean- the Government of the Patiala and East Punjab State Union or any of the Indian States which formed into the Patiala and East Punjab States Union on the 20th August, 1948 and the Government of the State of Punjab and all predecessor Governments thereof by whatever name called, the Governor-General or the Governor-General in Council, as the case may be, and the Sikh Rulers, but shall number include the Central Government as defined in the General Clauses Act, 1897, after the period companymencing on the 15th August, 1947.

issues.text: The question that rises for our decision in the above writ petitions and appeals is whether certain jagirs in the State of Punjab known as the Cis-Sutlej jagir are liable to be resumed under the provisions of the Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1957 (Punjab Act No. 39 of 1957), hereinafter referred to as the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question that rises for our decision in the above writ petitions and appeals is whether certain jagirs in the State of Punjab known as the Cis- Sutlej jagir are liable to be resumed under the provisions of the Punjab Resumption

issues.text: Whether the Act was ultra vires the powers of the State Legislature and that its provisions were unconstitutional and void

anchor.surface_text: A number of petitions were thereupon filed in the High Court of Punjab under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the Act and of the proceedings taken by the respondent State thereunder on the ground, firstly, that the Act was ultra vires

issues.text: Whether even if the Act was intra vires the jagirs held by the petitioners were not jagirs as defined in the Act, and were therefore not liable to be resumed under its provisions

precedents.citation: Thakar Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan  2

anchor.surface_text: Thakar Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan  2  with reference to a class of jagirdars in the State of Rajasthan known as Bhomicharas. They were once the rulers of the territories which were claimed to be jagirs, and later on the State of Jodhpur imposed its suzerainty over them and exacted an annual payment called Foujbal.

precedents.case_name: Thakar Amar Singhji v State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: a grant may be implied as well as express, and that on the facts proved, the Bhomicharas were reduced to the status of jagirdars under an implied grant
precedents.cited_holding: the Bhomicharas, though they held originally as rulers, must be held to have been reduced to the status of subjects, and that their position was that of jagirdars under an implied grant

anchor.surface_text: The position of the Cis-Sutlej jagirdars bears a close analogy to that of the Bhomicharas in Thakur Amar Singjis case  2 . They became rulers of the territories when they took possession of them by companyquest in 1763.

precedents.case_name: Thakur Amar Singhji v State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: close analogy in status reduction from rulers to jagirdars

precedents.citation: Cook v. Sir James Gordon Sprigg  1

anchor.surface_text: Thus, discussing what is an ,act of State, the Judicial Committee observed in Cook v. Sir James Gordon Sprigg  1  - The taking possession by Her Majesty, whether by cession or by any other means by which sovereignty can be acquired, was an act of State

precedents.case_name: Cook v Sir James Gordon Sprigg
precedents.cited_proposition: sovereignty can be acquired by cession or any other means besides conquest
precedents.cited_holding: The taking possession by Her Majesty, whether by cession or by any other means by which sovereignty can be acquired, was an act of State

precedents.citation: Vajesing Jaravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India in Council  2

anchor.surface_text: To the same effect are the following observations of Lord Danedin in Vajesing Jaravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India in Council  2  - When a territory is acquired by a sovereign State for the first time, that is an act of State.

precedents.case_name: Vajesingji Jaravarsingji v Secretary of State for India
precedents.cited_proposition: acquisition of territory by sovereign is act of State regardless of mode: conquest, cession, occupation
precedents.cited_holding: It matters number how the acquisition has been brought about. It may be by companyquest, it may be by cession following on treaty, it may be by occupation of territory hitherto unoccupied by a recognised ruler.

precedents.citation: M s. Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd.v. The Commissioner of Income-tax  3

anchor.surface_text: Laying down the law in similar terms, this Court observed in M s. Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd.v. The Commissioner of Income-tax  3  - The expression act of State is, it is scarcely necessary to say number limited to hostile

precedents.case_name: Dalmia Dadri Cement Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: act of State includes all acquisitions of territory by sovereign for first time, by conquest or cession
precedents.cited_holding: It includes all acquisitions of torritory by a sovereign State for the first time, whether it be by companyquest or cession.

precedents.citation: Promod Chandra Deb v. The State of Orissa  1

anchor.surface_text: And, more recently, this question has been companysidered by this Court in Promod Chandra Deb v. The State of Orissa  1 , and the result was thus stated - Act of State is the taking over of sovereign powers by a State

precedents.case_name: Promod Chandra Deb v State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Act of State is taking over sovereign powers over previously external territory by conquest, treaty, cession or otherwise
precedents.cited_holding: Act of State is the taking over of sovereign powers by a State in respect of territory which was number till then a part of its territory, either by companyquest treaty or cession, or otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this identical companytention, this Court observed in Thakur Amar Singhjis case  1  The status of a person must be either that of a sovereign or a subject. There is numbertertium quid.

precedents.case_name: Thakur Amar Singhji v State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: no intermediate status between sovereign and subject
precedents.cited_holding: The status of a person must be either that of a sovereign or a subject. There is numbertertium quid. The law does number recognise an intermediate status of a person being partly a sovereign and partly a subject

anchor.surface_text: It must be mentioned that in Abdul Ghafoor Khan v. Amar arji Singh, Regular Second Appeal No. 561 of 1946 in the Punjab High Court there are ob. servations of the learned Judges. precedents.case_name: Abdul Ghafoor Khan v Amar Singhji
precedents.cited_proposition: no gift or assignment of land revenue by British to Cis-Sutlej jagirdars

anchor.surface_text: Our attention has been invited to the decision of this Courtin Satinder Singh v. Umrao Singh 1 , where companypensation awarded on the acquisition of jagir lands was apportioned equally between the jagirdar and his son.

precedents.cited_proposition: compensation on acquisition of jagir lands apportioned between jagirdar and son

precedents.cited_proposition: no order on payment unless decision on rights of parties
